title: AB 250
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward" and "distant site" for health care providers. The amended Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code defines key terms for telemedicine, including "health care provider" as a licensed individual or a marriage and family therapist intern, "originating site" where services are provided via telecommunications, and "synchronous interaction" as real-time communication between a patient and a distant health care provider. Telehealth is the delivery of healthcare services through technology to facilitate diagnosis, treatment, education, and patient self-management. It includes synchronous interactions between patients and healthcare providers at distant sites. Prior to delivering healthcare via telehealth, the provider must inform the patient, obtain consent, and document it. Patients can still receive in-person care if they agree to telehealth first. Non-compliance is considered unprofessional conduct. The failure to comply with telehealth regulations is considered unprofessional conduct. Telehealth does not change the scope of practice for healthcare providers or allow services in unauthorized settings. Patient confidentiality laws apply to telehealth interactions, except for those under correctional facility jurisdiction. The hospital's governing body can grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers based on medical staff recommendations. This does not apply to patients under correctional facility jurisdiction. The Legislature intends to authorize hospitals to grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Applicants for licensure exams must complete a minimum of 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks. Section 4980.43 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require applicants to complete 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks for licensure exams. This experience must include a minimum of 1,700 hours after obtaining a qualifying master's or doctoral degree. The applicant must complete 1,700 hours of supervised experience after obtaining a qualifying master's or doctoral degree. Additionally, no more than 1,300 hours of supervised experience can be obtained before completing the degree. No hours of experience can be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. Additionally, no more than 1,000 hours of experience can be gained in direct supervisor contact. Not more than 1,000 hours of experience can be gained in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities related to marriage and family therapy. Professional enrichment activities include workshops, seminars, training sessions, or conferences approved by the supervisor, with a limit of 250 hours for attendance. The applicant can participate in personal psychotherapy for up to 100 hours, with three hours of experience credited for each hour. Additionally, they can gain up to 500 hours of experience in group therapy or counseling. For hours gained after January 1, 2012, they can have up to 500 hours in administering tests, writing reports, client advocacy, and related activities. For hours gained on or after January 1, 2012, a maximum of 500 hours of experience is allowed in administering psychological tests, client advocacy, and related activities. Additionally, a minimum of 500 hours of experience is required in diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, with a credit of two hours for each hour of conjoint therapy provided. Up to 375 hours of experience is permitted in providing personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or other counseling services via telehealth. (11) Up to 375 hours of experience in providing personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or other counseling services via telehealth. (12) Encouraged to work with elders and dependent adults with limitations. Only applies to hours gained after January 1, 2010. All applicants, trainees, and registrants must be supervised by a qualified supervisor to ensure counseling is in line with their training. Supervised experience can only be gained as an employee or volunteer, and all laws and regulations must be followed. Interns and trainees can only gain experience as an employee or volunteer, not as an independent contractor. The requirements for hours of experience and supervision apply to both employees and volunteers. Interns must provide W-2 tax forms or a letter from their employer verifying volunteer work when applying for licensure. Supervision must include one hour of direct contact per week in each work setting, except for experience gained under specific circumstances. Supervision for trainees must include one hour of direct supervisor contact per week for every five hours of client contact in each setting, with a maximum of six hours credited per week. A trainee must have one hour of direct supervisor contact for every five hours of client contact, with a maximum of six hours credited per week. Additional supervision is required for individuals with more than 10 hours of client contact per week after obtaining a qualifying degree. Direct supervisor contact is defined as one hour per week of face-to-face contact on an individual basis or two hours per week in a group of up to eight supervisees. The contact must occur within the same week as the hours claimed and in segments lasting no less than one continuous hour. (4) Direct supervisor contact must occur within the same week as claimed hours. (5) Group supervisor contact should involve no more than eight supervisees and last at least one continuous hour. (6) Interns in specific settings can use videoconferencing for weekly supervisor contact. (7) The supervisor must monitor all trainee experience as per regulations. A trainee's experience must be monitored by a supervisor as per regulations. Supervised experience completed in a setting providing mental health counseling and oversight can be credited to the trainee. The trainee's work must meet supervision requirements and be within the scope of practice. The setting cannot be owned by certain licensed professionals. Experience can only be gained through the trainee's volunteer or employment position. An intern can gain supervised experience in a mental health counseling setting that meets specific requirements. They cannot work in a private practice until registered as an intern. An applicant must be registered as an intern before working in a private practice. Interns can be paid or volunteer, with employers encouraged to provide fair remuneration. Employers are encouraged to provide fair remuneration to interns, who must be under the direct supervision of a licensee in private practice, except during supervisor's vacation or sick leave. All individuals must register as interns with the board to receive credit for postdegree supervised experience towards licensure, except when working in a private practice. Postdegree experience can be credited towards licensure if the applicant applies for intern registration within 90 days of receiving their qualifying degree. Trainees, interns, and applicants must not receive payment from patients or clients, only from their employers. Trainees, interns, and applicants must perform services at their employer's place of business under supervision and in compliance with laws. They may also provide services via telehealth under licensed supervision. Trainees and interns working under licensed supervision may provide telehealth services within authorized scope and regulations. They must not have a proprietary interest in their employers' businesses or pay for any obligations. Trainees, interns, or applicants receiving up to $500 per month for expenses incurred while providing services in a lawful work setting are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to verify expenses reimbursement. Each educational institution and supervisor should consider encouraging students, interns, and trainees to undergo counseling or psychotherapy as appropriate. Assistance in locating affordable counseling services should be provided if desired by the applicant.
